dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, the recent Biden-Xi summit, right? We saw some pretty significant developments come out of that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, the recent Biden Xi summit, right? We saw some pretty significant developments come out of that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication, thereby reducing the chances of an accidental conflict, and China will do more to restrict the export of chemicals used to make the powerful synthetic opioid fentanyl a major cause of death in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Host_A, definitely. I mean, the resumption of military-to-military communication, that's, uh, crucial for reducing accidental conflicts, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Host A, definitely. I mean, the resumption of military to military communication, that's, uh, crucial for reducing accidental conflicts, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication, thereby reducing the chances of an accidental conflict...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And China agreeing to clamp down on fentanyl chemical exports? That's, like, a huge win for the US.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And China agreeing to clamp down on fentanyl chemical exports? That's, like, a huge win for the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and China will do more to restrict the export of chemicals used to make the powerful synthetic opioid fentanyl a major cause of death in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But there was one pretty glaring omission, wasn't there? The, um, elephant in the room, so to speak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But there was one pretty glaring omission, wasn't there? The, um, elephant in the room, so to speak.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! I mean, remember Trump's administration? They really hiked those rates. From, what, like 3% to over 21%?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! I mean, remember Trump's administration? They really hiked those rates. From, what, like three percent to over twenty one percent?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21%...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a level we hadn't seen since before World War II. And, uh, China retaliated in kind, of course.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a level we hadn't seen since before World War Two. And, uh, China retaliated in kind, of course.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...a level unseen in the US since before World War II. This prompted China to retaliate with higher tariffs on US imports from about 8% to some 19%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So we've been in this kind of, like, trade war limbo ever since. And the article really highlights how much it hurts us.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So we've been in this kind of, like, trade war limbo ever since. And the article really highlights how much it hurts us.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does! Every serious study shows those increased costs get passed straight onto American consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does! Every serious study shows those increased costs get passed straight onto American consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every serious study of the issue suggests that the increased costs arising from the tariffs have been passed onto American consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and not just on finished goods. A huge chunk of those imports are, um, parts for our own manufacturers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and not just on finished goods. A huge chunk of those imports are, um, parts for our own manufacturers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So if we just removed these tariffs, the article suggests it could lower the cost of living for Americans by, like, a whole percentage point permanently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if we just removed these tariffs, the article suggests it could lower the cost of living for Americans by, like, a whole percentage point permanently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, what, equivalent to an extra $250 billion in household income a year? That's massive!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, what, equivalent to an extra two hundred fifty billion dollars in household income a year? That's massive!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Put another way, this would be equivalent of an increase in US household income by more than $250 billion per year (1% of US GDP in 2022).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So then, like, why didn't Biden even touch it? The US Trade Representative didn't even go to San Francisco.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So then, like, why didn't Biden even touch it? The U S Trade Representative didn't even go to San Francisco.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And yet, despite the benefits that reducing tariffs would bring, the US Trade Representative did not attend the San Francisco summit, suggesting that Biden never intended to discuss the issue at all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the thinking is, um, he doesn't want to look "soft on China" to Republicans, right? But he could really use a win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the thinking is, um, he doesn't want to look soft on China to Republicans, right? But he could really use a win.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is said that Biden does not want to give the Republicans a reason to say that he is soft on China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He really could. Voters are super concerned about the cost of living, and his economic approval numbers are, uh, pretty low.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He really could. Voters are super concerned about the cost of living, and his economic approval numbers are, uh, pretty low.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is facing a highly contentious election next year, and the rising cost of living is voters number one economic concern. ... In a recent poll, just 14% of American voters reported being better off financially now than when Biden took office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Even among Democrats, apparently, which is like, a huge red flag. This seems like such a clear opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even among Democrats, apparently, which is like, a huge red flag. This seems like such a clear opportunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the fact that fewer than half of Democrats believe his policies have helped the economy, even a little, should be setting off alarm bells to the president.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really does. It feels like a missed chance to help American households directly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really does. It feels like a missed chance to help American households directly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. A real, uh, failure of leadership, to not even try to communicate those benefits to voters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. A real, uh, failure of leadership, to not even try to communicate those benefits to voters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But he should communicate to voters that removing the Trump tariffs would be good for American households and firms. Not doing so is a failure of leadership.
